masterFinding.remediationInstructions:
Do not store unencrypted social security numbers in any location. That includes, but is not limited to:
  • Binaries

  • Configuration files

  • Scripts

  • Windows registry

  • Databases


Use a strong encryption method to protect social security numbers. Below is a list of potential security controls that can help reduce the risk of sensitive information disclosure. However, please be aware that each option carries different levels of risk.
  • Encrypt data using database server functionality to protect it during run-time

  • Encrypt data using the application to protect it during run-time

  • Use file-level encryption to protect database and other sensitive files if the disk becomes physically accessible

  • Use full disk encryption to protect the database if the disk becomes physically accessible

  • Encrypt database and server backups
masterFinding.name: Unencrypted Storage of Social Security Numbers
masterFinding.businessImpact:
A threat agent may be able to gain unauthorized access to social security numbers through several vectors including, but not limited to:
*Direct database access from the database server
*Database access through the application
*Physical access to the database server hard drive
*Logical or physical access to the database and server backup tapes and files

In the event of an incident, revenue could be loss due to brand damage, fines, and penalties.
masterFinding.description: Unencrypted social security numbers were discovered.
